name: Selma Lagerlöfs Center
subtitle: 92% interior reuse with 70% cost savings - Sweden's largest interior reuse project
data_source: CCBuild/Circular Hub + White Års- och hållbarhetsrapport 2019

executive_summary.headline: 92% interior furnishings from reused sources - demonstrating commercial viability of large-scale interior reuse
key_achievements: 92% of interior furnishings from reused sources
70% cost savings (9 MSEK) vs new furniture procurement
Sweden's largest interior reuse project at opening (2019)
Design S Award 2020 for Interior Architecture
Innovative 'Selma stamp' branding for all reused items
Patchwork table from reclaimed tabletops and laminate boards
Trade fair flooring repurposed as library shelving
executive_summary.why_tier2: High reuse limited to interior fit-out, not building structure. Excellent cost savings data and process documentation. Structure is new build.

interior_architect.name: Annie Leonsson
interior_architect.role: Lead interior architect for reuse project

furniture_partner.name: C&D Snickeri
furniture_partner.business_model: Owned, stored and refurbished furniture based on White's designs

materials.description: 92% of interior furnishings from reused sources - largest at opening
Purchased second-hand furniture from reuse market to supplement internal stock
Large entry hall table assembled from reclaimed tabletops and laminate boards
Trade fair booth flooring repurposed as library shelving material

co2_reduction.note: Lower climate impact documented but not quantified in kg CO2e

business_model.innovation: C&D Snickeri owned, stored and refurbished furniture based on designs

key_insights: 92% interior reuse achievable at 70% cost savings
New business models enable scaling (furniture ownership by contractor)
Visual branding ('Selma stamp') unifies diverse reused items
'Confetti' approach accepts diverse styles rather than matching sets
Interior reuse is lower barrier entry point for circular construction
success_factors: Innovative business model with C&D Snickeri
Accept diversity in materials and styles
challenges: Coordinating furniture from six different operations
Quality control for varied reused items
Creating visual coherence with diverse sources

narrative.driver: GöteborgsLokaler wanted to demonstrate large-scale interior reuse is commercially viable.
narrative.approach: Innovative business model where C&D Snickeri owned, stored and refurbished furniture. 'Selma stamp' branded all reused items. 'Confetti' approach accepted diverse styles.
narrative.significance: Proved 92% interior reuse achievable with 70% cost savings. Established replicable business model.
narrative.legacy: Model for interior reuse in public buildings across Sweden.
